choices.F: SELECT * FROM employees WHERE salary + NVL(commission, 0) >= 20000;
choices.E: SELECT * FROM employees WHERE COALESCE(salary, commission) >= 20000;
choices.B: SELECT * FROM employees WHERE salary + NVL2(commission, commission, 0) >= 20000
choices.A: SELECT * FROM employees WHERE NVL2(salary + commission, salary + commission, salary) >= 20000;
choices.C: SELECT * FROM employees WHERE NVL(salary + commission, 0) >= 20000;
choices.D: SELECT * FROM employees WHERE salary + NULLIF(commission, 0) >= 20000;

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ABF
ABF is the correct answer

Selected Answer: ABF
ABF is the correct answer

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about Structured Query Language (SQL)? (Choose three.)

discussion.content: A needs to be heard as well.
I think the answer should be BCD as SQL is used for both RDBMS and Object Oriented DB. Regarding atomicity and consistency, I think that is facilitated by the RDBMS engine.

Selected Answer: BCE
Answers are B, C, E.
A is also true my reference is https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/23/sqlrf/Hierarchical-Queries.html#GUID-0118DF1D-B9A9-41EB-8556-C6E7D6A5A84E

comments.content: so i think the true answer is ACE

discussion.content: BCF CORRECT
BCE is the correct answer
answer is BCE
Answer is ACE

choices.D: It is the only language that can be used for both relational and object-oriented databases.
choices.A: It requires that data be contained in hierarchical data storage.
choices.E: It guarantees atomicity, consistency, isolation, and durability (ACID) features.
choices.F: It is used to define encapsulation and polymorphism for a relational table.
choices.C: It provides independence for logical data structures being manipulated from the underlying physical data storage.

questions.question_text:
Examine the description of EMPLOYEES table:

//IMG//


The session time zone is the same as the database server.

Which two statements will list only the employees who have been working with the company for more than five years? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
missing 5 in the D query, otherwise these 2 are correct, CURRENT_DATE - hire_date and SYSDATE- hire_date return both results in days so we have to divide by 365
Eliminate ABC because of fact /12 .. in order to get year it should be /365.

Selected Answer: DE
DE should be the correct answer

Selected Answer: DE
DE is correct (even though D seems to be with typo). 
F is not correct as default precision of DAY is 2 - should be INTERVAL '1845' DAY(4)

Selected Answer: EF
I think EF.
D is with typo?

I think EF.
D is with typo?

Selected Answer: DE
DE is correct

choices.B: SELECT employee_name FROM employees WHERE (SYSTIMSSTAMF - hire_date) / 12 > INTERVAL '5' YEAR;
choices.A: SELECT employee_name FROM employees WHERE (SYSDATE - hire_date) / 12 > 5;
choices.D: SELECT employee_name FROM employees WHERE (CURRENT_DATE - hire_date) / 365 >
choices.E: SELECT employee_name FROM employees WHERE (SYSDATE - hire_date) / 365 > 5;
choices.C: SELECT employee_name FROM employees WHERE (CURRENT_DATE - hire_date) / 12 > 5
choices.F: SELECT employee_name FROM employees WHERE (SYSTIMESTAMP - hire_date) / 365 > INTERVAL '1825' DAY;

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about the DESCRIBE command? (Choose three.)

choices.B: It displays the PRIMARY KEY constraint for any column or columns that have that constraint.
choices.E: It can be used only from SQL* Plus.
choices.C: It displays all constraints that are defined for each column.
choices.D: It displays the NOT NULL constraint for any columns that have that constraint.
choices.A: It can be used from SQL Developer.
choices.F: It can be used to display the structure of an existing view.
